Don't forget the environmental costs. I am no tree hugger, but even I have limits to what lengths I am willing to go to in order to be able to fill up my pickup cheaply.

 
 I've been to the Suncor mine at Ft. McMurray as well. It's not pretty, but it's acutally remarkably clean in terms of air, ground and water pollution. The biggest impact on the environment is actually in the volume of water that is used in the process and is extracted from the Athabasca River. The actual impact on the earth's surface from the open pit mining process, while it seems immense now, will actually be very minimal once all the reclamation processes are completed. I've seen open pit coal strip mines in southern Sask from the 50's and 60's that are now beautiful wildlife areas, and the reclamation effort spent on these sites was nearly zero.
 
 Unfortunately, as stated, the cost of this environmental stewardship on a per barrel basis makes competition with ME oil a struggle.
